results.title: John Davis
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Shows the work of Victorian sculptor John Davis, who uses many unusual materials and concepts to create modern sculpture

results.title: John Lethbridge
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
John Lethbridge’s works, his paintings, drawings and sculptural installations develop out of a personal necessity to try to give an order to the rituals and repeating experiences of life that recur in an apparently unordered and random world. His recent work can be described as “Post Conceptual Romanticism”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Imants Tillers
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, Michael Bongiovanni and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Imants Tillers along with Peter Myers and Peter Rees use the example of Bankstown, New South Wales to discuss the constructed and artificial landscape in terms of Australian culture and the relationship between art making and suburbinisation. Bankstown is a town constructed on landfill. It epitomises and celebrates the ‘height’ of suburban aesthetic values. Tillers, Myers and Rees explore themes of the ‘fulfilled suburban dream’, the suburban ‘visual’ language, Australian Futurism in architecture. Bankstown is the quintessential Australian suburb in its exuberance to express and celebrate urban pride. Some interesting observations are made along the way. The houses are: locked within parameters of essential design elements, with identical floor plans and no fence lines that allow each house to sit like artwork on walls for display reinstituting the notion of ‘promenade’. [PRINT IS A DUB-COPY]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, Michael Bongiovanni and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Tom Arthur
results.creator_credit: National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Tom Arthur’s art is for him a visual way of reasoning. By using the associated symbolic meanings and cultural connotations attached to specific objects and images he attempts to examine and question belief structures and systems of knowledge and how society forces these into its members. For Tom Arthur there are no absolutes, and everything seems relative

results.title: Martin Sharp
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, Ken Otton, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Part of a series which looks at individual artists and their works. Martin Sharp discusses his beginnings as a cartoonist for Oz magazine in the sixties and his many styles of painting. Sharp’s art has always reflected the concerns of his own personal world and in that sense is highly diaristic, recording images people and objects that have contributed to his perception of the world.

results.title: On Paper
results.creator_credit: Ray Harris, Michael Bongiovanni, Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
The connecting link in this video is photography, and the different approaches Micky Allan, Sally Robinson, Mandy Martin and Jenny Watson have to producing works on paper using photography either directly or indirectly

results.title: Survey 12: on paper
results.creator_credit: Ray Harris, Michael Bongiovanni, Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Part of a series which looks at individual artists and their works. This program interviews four artists, Micky Allan, Mandy Martin, Sally Robinson and Jenny Watson. Each artist discusses their philosophies, influences, subject matter, background in art, methods, materials and work. Each has been influenced by or incorporates photography in their work.

results.title: Tony Mcgillick
results.creator_credit: National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Looks at a collection of paintings by modern artist Tony McGillick, the earliest of which dates back to 1964

results.title: Rosalie Gascoigne
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Rosalie Gascoigne talks about her work and interests. She is a self-taught assemblage artist who uses weathered, discarded junk from man-made objects and found objects from nature. Her assemblages create images of domestic country kitchens while her late installations have an outdoor open feeling for country air and light
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
